Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of Interacting Particle Systems by Stochastic Analysis Methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Interacting particle systems originate from mathematical physics, but are now used in a number of areas in applied mathematics. Among others, they can be used to model phenomena such as capital distribution in equity markets, fluid dynamics, stability of queueing networks, and traffic flow. The main goal of this project is to obtain a better mathematical understanding of interacting particle systems and to relate them to other mathematical objects, including partial differential equations, random matrices, random polymers, random Young tableaux, and symmetric functions. Such detailed mathematical analysis would provide new information on the applicability of interacting particle systems as mathematical models within the fields described above, as well as on their limitations. In addition, with the mathematics of interacting particle systems being on the interface of probability theory, partial differential equations, and representation theory, the proposed research is expected to unveil connections between these areas of mathematics. Such connections are of great interest as they allow one to combine tools from all these different areas in future research.

More specifically, the PI intends to study interacting particle systems with continuous state spaces in which the particle dynamics can be described by interacting Brownian (or, more generally, diffusive) motions. Typically, such systems are the continuous analogues of the more classical discrete interacting particle systems. However, the continuity of the state space allows one to apply methods of stochastic analysis to such systems and is natural due to the continuous nature of the (stochastic) partial differential equations describing the macroscopic behavior of interacting particle systems. In particular, the PI intends to study systems in the Kardar-Parisi-Zhang universality class, which describes the microscopic dynamics behind the growth of random surfaces. Examples of such systems include, among others, the Brownian totally asymmetric simple exclusion process and the O'Connell-Yor semi-discrete polymer. In this context one is particularly interested in the asymptotic behavior of the leading particles and the spacings between them, and their investigation is a major part of the proposed research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has been devoted to the study of interacting particle systems, which are central objects in probability theory with many applications outside and inside mathematics. Generally speaking, interacting particle systems can be used as models for any system with interacting components, such as the prices of different financial securities, financial institutions borrowing and lending from each other, networks of computers exchanging data, physical particles in a gas or liquid, among numerous other examples.

In this context, some of the main results of the project were the following: a detailed description of the performance of functionally generated portfolios, e.g. index-tracking or equal-weighted portfolios, has been obtained; a model for the mechanism behind systemic crises has been proposed and, within such, the effects of the lending network and of the strategic behavior by financial institutions have been analyzed in detail; the effects of changes in investor's preferences on the portfolio optimal for her have been described; and a new method for studying the sample covariance matrices from high-dimensional data has been proposed.   

In terms of intellectual merit, the emergence of global phenomena from local triggers (describing e.g. synchronization of a large number of neurons in the brain, the defaults of a large number of institutions in the financial system etc.) has been quantified. This has been achieved by deriving the large scale behavior of a large class of interacting particle systems. The random fluctuations around the large scale behavior have been also investigated. In a similar vein, a new approach to large random matrices and their operator limits has been developed. In particular, it allows to understand the number of principal components/factors that need to be taken into account when studying the sample covariance matrices from high-dimensional data. These results have advanced probability theory, the theory of partial differential equations, mathematical physics and mathematical finance.
